data.title: Licence to Kill (1989)
data.meta_description: After capturing the notorious drug lord Franz Sanchez, Bond's close friend and former CIA agent Felix Leiter is left for dead and his wife is murdered. Bond goes rogue and seeks vengeance on those responsible, as he infiltrates Sanchez's organization from the inside.
data.text:
One of my favourite Bond films, this one shook off the Moore-era humour and instead had something far more violent and realistic.

Carey Lowell is a wonderfully sparky girl associate for 007, even if Talisa Soto is a bit of a drip. The basic premise of this one is that Bond goes solo and rogue after witnessing the murder of his friend Felix Leiter's bride on her wedding day, and the mutilation of Leiter.

The bad guys are an international drug cartel led by Robert Davi, and there are lots of cover stories and twists to keep the interest, including a corrupt man of God (Wayne Newton). Benicio del Toro is a monster of a sidekick and there are some…

Fuera de Serie: Bond, James Bond - The International Spy, The Icon & The Once Serial Women Beater

Up to this point the 007 movies have shown us the most chivalrous, misogynistic and comical side of the character, now we get to witness James Bond's most vengeful and bloodthirsty side. This time Bond finds himself in the most tense and personal situation that even leads him to break the rules and orders of his superiors, aided with the little help of the typical Bond girl who assists him to eliminate a drug dealer who tried to hurt his most beloved friend.

Even to this day, this installment is probably the most violent of the franchise. Sure, many of the previous installments…

Geoff T's James Bond-a-Thon #16

Licence to Kill (1989)

The second and sadly final outing of Timothy Dalton's films as 007, and the fifth (and last) entry directed by John Glen, License to Kill still earns it's spot as one of the darker and more brutal entries in the series (contributing to a higher certificate than usual by the censors). Nevertheless, it's a personal favourite and in my view, one of my most underrated Bond flicks.

Here, we stray away from the traditional Bond storyline which focuses on the MI6 agent setting off on his own personal vendetta. The key villain is Franz Sanchez (Robert Davi), a ruthless drug lord who after being broken out by corrupt DEA agent Ed…

"I help people with problems."

"Problem solver."

"More of a problem eliminator."

Bond gets personal.

Licence to Kill opens with a brilliantly cross-cut, two-level conflict: James Bond and Felix Leiter are on a mission to stop dangerous drug lord Franz Sanchez—and Bond has to get Leiter back in time for his wedding. They succeed, of course, but Sanchez escapes and captures Leiter. Assuming the worst, Bond embarks on a quest for vengeance.

The motivation in almost every single James Bond film up until this point (with the possible but questionable exception of On Her Majesty’s Secret Service) has been to save the world and have as much fun doing so as possible. Some Bad Guy gets his hands on some…
